meanings.def: something that is being carried (usually in large amounts) by a person, vehicle, etc.
examples: The trucks waited at the warehouse to pick up their loads.
load of something The women came down the hill with their loads of firewood.
These backpacks are designed to carry a heavy load.
A lorry shed its load (= accidentally dropped its load) on the motorway.
(figurative) The company's debt load could drag it into bankruptcy.

meanings.def: the total amount of something that something can carry or contain
examples: a busload of tourists
They ordered three truckloads of sand.
He put half a load of washing in the machine.
The plane took off with a full load.
Maximum load, including passengers, is 800 pounds.

meanings.def: the amount of weight that is pressing down on something
examples: a load-bearing wall
Modern backpacks spread the load over a wider area.
The table creaked under its heavy load.

meanings.def: a large number or amount of people or things; plenty
examples: a load/loads of somebody/something She's got loads of friends.
He wrote loads and loads of letters to people.
Uncle Jim brought a whole load of presents for the kids.
We saw a load of houses before we bought this one.
They all had loads of fun at the park.
In my job I get the chance to meet loads of different people.
a load/loads to do There's loads to do today.

meanings.def: used to emphasize that something is wrong, stupid, bad, etc.
examples: You're talking a load of rubbish.

meanings.def: an amount of work that a person or machine has to do
examples: Teaching loads have increased in all types of school.
Extra warmth from sunlight can put an additional load on the air-conditioning system.
We're trying to spread the load by employing more staff.

meanings.def: a feeling of responsibility or worry that is difficult to deal with
examples: She thought she would not be able to bear the load of bringing up her family alone.
Knowing that they had arrived safely took a load off my mind.
Many companies are burdened by high debt loads.

meanings.def: the amount of electrical power that is being supplied at a particular time
used to tell somebody to look at or listen to somebody/something
examples: Get a load of that dress!

idioms.def: used to tell somebody to look at or listen to somebody/something
examples: Get a load of that dress!

related: load the dice (against/in favour of somebody)
a brick short of a load, two sandwiches short of a picnic, etc.

meanings.def: to put a large quantity of things or people onto or into something
examples: load something We loaded the car in ten minutes.
Can you help me load the dishwasher?
load something up They loaded up the lorry.
load something up with something Men were loading up a truck with timber.
load something with something Lastly came six wagons loaded with coal.
load something/somebody onto something Sacks were being loaded onto the truck.
load something/somebody into something The paramedics loaded Jason into the ambulance.
We finished loading and set off.
load up We got back to the car and began loading up.
The ship was still loading.

meanings.def: to give somebody a lot of things, especially things they have to carry
examples: They loaded her with gifts.

meanings.def: to put something into a weapon, camera or other piece of equipment so that it can be used
examples: load something (into something) She loaded a new cartridge into the printer.
load something (with something) She loaded the printer with a new cartridge.
load (something) Is the gun loaded?

meanings.def: to put data or a program into the memory of a computer, usually from local disk storage
examples: The program automatically loads the file.
This page won't load on my laptop.

meanings.def: to put somebody at an unfair disadvantage/advantage
examples: He has always felt that the dice were loaded against him in life.
This is another attempt to load the dice in favour of employers.

idioms.idiom: load the dice (against/in favour of somebody)
idioms.def: to put somebody at an unfair disadvantage/advantage
examples: He has always felt that the dice were loaded against him in life.
This is another attempt to load the dice in favour of employers.
